input: Dave is big. Dave is round. Dave is smart. Erin is blue. Fiona is big. Fiona is green. Fiona is smart. Harry is big. Harry is green. Harry is rough. Harry is smart. Harry is young. If something is young and rough then it is round. All smart things are rough. If something is round then it is green. If something is rough and big then it is young. Blue things are smart. Rough, smart things are young. Question: Erin is not green.?
output:
universe u

constant obj : Type u

constant Dave : obj
constant Erin : obj
constant Fiona : obj
constant Harry : obj

constant Big : obj → Prop
constant Round : obj → Prop
constant Smart : obj → Prop
constant Blue : obj → Prop
constant Green : obj → Prop
constant Rough : obj → Prop
constant Young : obj → Prop

axiom T1 : Big Dave
axiom T2 : Round Dave
axiom T3 : Smart Dave
axiom T4 : Blue Erin
axiom T5 : Big Fiona
axiom T6 : Green Fiona
axiom T7 : Smart Fiona
axiom T8 : Big Harry
axiom T9 : Green Harry
axiom T10 : Rough Harry
axiom T11 : Smart Harry
axiom T12 : Young Harry

axiom R1 : ∀ x : obj, Young x ∧ Rough x → Round x
axiom R2 : ∀ x : obj, Smart x → Rough x
axiom R3 : ∀ x : obj, Round x → Green x
axiom R4 : ∀ x : obj, Rough x ∧ Big x → Young x
axiom R5 : ∀ x : obj, Blue x → Smart x
axiom R6 : ∀ x : obj, Rough x ∧ Smart x → Young x

theorem erin_is_not_green : ¬ Green Erin :=
begin
  sorry
end

-- Looks like it cannot be proven in Lean.
-- So let's try to prove the negation of the theorem, which is Erin is green

theorem erin_is_green : Green Erin :=
begin
  apply R3,
  apply R1,
  split,
  apply R6,
  split,
  apply R5,
  exact T4,
  apply R2,
  apply R5,
  exact T4,
  apply R2,
  apply R5,
  exact T4,
end

-- It can be proven in Lean. So
-- The answer is False
